channel.title: Exploring the child's world
channel.description:
Interviews with delinquent and disturbed young people who are encouraged to discuss their experiences and express feelings. To protect individuals, each program is a re-creation of an actual interview using different names and places.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Nagging parents
item.description: This program focuses on "nagging parents" and their role in a child's problems.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Religious factors in upset
item.description: This program explores religious factors that could be involved in children's delinquency.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Institutional posture
item.description: This program focuses on "institutional posture" or the concept that some delinquent children don't learn how to cope outside of institutional settings.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: The presenting problem
item.description: This program focuses on the "presenting problem," or a situation where a different problem is presented by the child than the one they actually need help with.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Personality traits
item.description: This program focuses on the personality traits of delinquent children.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Anomie
item.description: This program focuses on anomie, the concept that society doesn't provide enough moral guidance to children and others.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Self defense
item.description: This program looks at howa child's misbehavior can be a form of self defense.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Differential association
item.description: This program focuses on differential association, a theory that proposes that children's negative behaviors are learned from others.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: The lonely boy
item.description: This program focuses on how loneliness and isolation can be at the root of juvenile delinquency.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Bad companions
item.description: This program focuses on how the negative influence of other children can lead to a child's delinquency.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: School problem
item.description: This program focuses on how troubles in school can be at the root of juvenile delinquency.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: The quiet child
item.description: This program focuses on how quiet and introverted children can fall into delinquency.
item.dc:creator: Duquesne University
item.dc:subject: Sociology
